pitrou commented on PR #14497:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14497#issuecomment-1290549901

   It's weird that the compilation command line for Arrow CUDA (and only Arrow CUDA) did not include `-isystem /arrow/cpp/thirdparty/flatbuffers/include` as expected. @kou Do you have an idea why that would be?

pitrou commented on PR #14497:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14497#issuecomment-1290564104

   More exactly, this is the compilation command that succeeded locally:
   ```
   /usr/local/bin/sccache /usr/lib/ccache/c++  -DARROW_EXPORTING -DARROW_HAVE_RUNTIME_AVX2 -DARROW_HAVE_RUNTIME_AVX512 -DARROW_HAVE_RUNTIME_BMI2 -DARROW_HAVE_RUNTIME_SSE4_2 -DARROW_HAVE_SSE4_2 -DARROW_NO_DEPRECATED_API -DARROW_WITH_BROTLI -DARROW_WITH_BZ2 -DARROW_WITH_LZ4 -DARROW_WITH_SNAPPY -DARROW_WITH_ZLIB -DARROW_WITH_ZSTD -DBOOST_ALL_NO_LIB -DURI_STATIC_BUILD -Isrc -I/arrow/cpp/src -I/arrow/cpp/src/generated -isystem /usr/local/cuda/include -isystem /arrow/cpp/thirdparty/flatbuffers/include -isystem /arrow/cpp/thirdparty/hadoop/include -isystem xsimd_ep/src/xsimd_ep-install/include -Wno-noexcept-type  -fdiagnostics-color=always -ggdb -O0  -Wall -Wno-conversion -Wno-sign-conversion -Wunused-result -Werror -fno-semantic-interposition -msse4.2  -g -fPIC   -pthread -std=c++17 -MD -MT src/arrow/gpu/CMakeFiles/arrow_cuda_objlib.dir/cuda_arrow_ipc.cc.o -MF src/arrow/gpu/CMakeFiles/arrow_cuda_objlib.dir/cuda_arrow_ipc.cc.o.d -o src/arrow/gpu/CMakeFiles/arrow_cuda_objlib.dir/cuda_arrow_ipc.cc.o -c /arrow/cpp/src/arrow/gpu/cuda_arrow_ipc.cc
   ```
   
   This is the line that failed on CI:
   ```
   /usr/local/bin/sccache /usr/lib/ccache/c++  -DARROW_EXPORTING -DARROW_HAVE_RUNTIME_AVX2 -DARROW_HAVE_RUNTIME_AVX512 -DARROW_HAVE_RUNTIME_BMI2 -DARROW_HAVE_RUNTIME_SSE4_2 -DARROW_HAVE_SSE4_2 -DARROW_NO_DEPRECATED_API -DARROW_WITH_BROTLI -DARROW_WITH_BZ2 -DARROW_WITH_LZ4 -DARROW_WITH_SNAPPY -DARROW_WITH_ZLIB -DARROW_WITH_ZSTD -DURI_STATIC_BUILD -Isrc -I/arrow/cpp/src -I/arrow/cpp/src/generated -isystem /usr/local/cuda/include -Wno-noexcept-type  -fdiagnostics-color=always -ggdb -O0  -Wall -Wno-conversion -Wno-sign-conversion -Wunused-result -Werror -fno-semantic-interposition -msse4.2  -g -fPIC   -std=c++17 -MD -MT src/arrow/gpu/CMakeFiles/arrow_cuda_objlib.dir/cuda_arrow_ipc.cc.o -MF src/arrow/gpu/CMakeFiles/arrow_cuda_objlib.dir/cuda_arrow_ipc.cc.o.d -o src/arrow/gpu/CMakeFiles/arrow_cuda_objlib.dir/cuda_arrow_ipc.cc.o -c /arrow/cpp/src/arrow/gpu/cuda_arrow_ipc.cc
   ```

Review Comment:
   It looks like it is running it via docker cli instead of docker-compose: 
   ```
   DEBUG:archery:Executing `['docker', 'run', '--rm', '-e', 'SETUPTOOLS_SCM_PRETEND_VERSION=10.0.0.dev509', '--gpus', 'all', '--shm-size', '2G', '-e', 'ARROW_BUILD_UTILITIES=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_COMPUTE=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_CSV=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_CUDA=ON', '-e', 'ARROW_DATASET=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_ENABLE_TIMING_TESTS=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_FILESYSTEM=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_GANDIVA=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_GCS=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_HDFS=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_JEMALLOC=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_JSON=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_ORC=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_PARQUET=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_PLASMA=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_S3=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_SUBSTRAIT=OFF', '-e', 'ARROW_WITH_OPENTELEMETRY=OFF', '-e', 'AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=None', '-e', 'AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=None', '-e', 'CCACHE_COMPILERCHECK=content', '-e', 'CCACHE_COMPRESS=1', '-e', 'CCACHE_COMPRESSLEVEL=6', '-e', 'CCACHE_DIR=/ccache', '-e', 'CCACHE_MAXSIZE=1G', '-e', 'SCCACHE_BUCKET=None', '-e', 'SCCACHE_S3_KEY_PREFIX=sccache', '-v', '/runner/_work/crossbow/crossbow/arrow:/arrow:delegated', '-v', 'ubuntu-ccache:/ccache:delegated', 'apache/arrow-dev:amd64-ubuntu-20.04-cuda-11.0.3-cpp', '/bin/bash', '-c', '\n  /arrow/ci/scripts/cpp_build.sh /arrow /build &&\n  /arrow/ci/scripts/integration_skyhook.sh /build &&\n  /arrow/ci/scripts/cpp_test.sh /arrow /build']`
   ```

assignUser commented on PR #14497:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14497#issuecomment-1291902711

   The issue was caused by a mismatch between the docker images used for the runner and the job, they apparently have to be the same image or at least have the same CUDA version down to patch level.

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
Arrow C++, PyArrow and perhaps other bindings have CUDA support, but none is currently tested on CI, and I think few of the contributors enable CUDA on their local builds.

We should definitely exercise CUDA support, at least in the nightly builds where we may have more flexibility to use custom machines.

comments.body: [~kou] [~raulcd] [~assignUser], can you try to collaborate on this?

Do we already have a machine that has Nvidia GPU and can be used for CI?
(Can Voltron Data provide it?)

Voltron Data / Ursa Computing used to have DGX machines but I'm not sure that's still the case.

That said, this doesn't need to be a dedicated physical machine, it can be some VM somewhere in the cloud.

OK.

It seems that we can use GitHub Actions' self-hosted runners with autoscalling. It will match this use case.

https://docs.github.com/en/actions/hosting-your-own-runners/autoscaling-with-self-hosted-runners
Yep, great idea! I will see if/where we can get some CUDA capable runners for crossbow. Will update when I know more.

[~amol-] [~assignUser] Can this be prioritized for 10.0.0? I think CUDA support has been untested for quite some time.
(I used to run it locally but cannot anymore because of issues with conda-forge)
With  ARROW-17423  and ARROW-17435 now fixed, the path is cleared for CUDA CI :-)
[~apitrou] Yes this is planned for 10.0.0  (or ideally prior to the actual release phase).

Probably easiest is to use GPUs that are hosted in the cloud. [CircleCI|https://circleci.com/pricing/] does have an offering  as does [CIrun|https://cirun.io/].  Probably an estimate of the number of GPU minutes needed per month would be helpful.
We will use self-hosted runners via crossbow, probably for nightlies only for now.
